thank you verer so the Amazon API Gateway is an incredibly simple way to
create robust scalable and secure rest apis literally in minutes and if you're
not familiar what are the components of a rest API there's really just three components the first is a series of
resources these resources in the abstract sense are the things of your application so if you're building a real
estate application this would be the houses and the properties and the prices of those properties if you're building
an auction application these would be the bids and the items that were available for auction and how rest apis
work is that you assign methods against those resources and access them at the end of a URL so you can assign htttp
requests methods like gets and posts and puts that you're used to using send those to a URL and interact with the
resources inside your application and what you respond with is a representation of your resource so this
representation may be HTML for a web application but it could be XML or Json or any other kind of interchange format
that you have and these three components form the backbone of the API uh Gateway
and you go about creating it in just three really easy ways the first thing you need to do is you want to be able to create your resources and this is as
simple as typing in a name and typing in the uh endpoint the URL endpoint that you want to be able to access that uh uh
resource on then you want to assign and attach your HTTP methods so you can just
assign gets and puts and posts and these usually map to the kind of crud create
retrieve update and delete operations that are familiar to many database users and at the ends of those methods you can
assign any publicly accessible endpoint so you can proxy into an application
which is running on ec2 you can proxy to any other application running on the Internet or you can use no servers
whatsoever and run Lambda applic Lambda uh Cloud functions in response to API
calls and you just go through and select the one you want it as easy as clicking in the
console finally you want to be able to take your resources and the methods that you've just defined and you want to be
able to deploy those so that you can access them and the API Gateway supports not just one version of an application
but multiple versions of the application and not just one environment stage but multiple and arbitrary uh environment
stages for your API so you can choose whether you want to deploy a particular version in a particular environment just
with a few clicks or ironically through the API Gateway API so you can choose to
run in Alpha Beta production anything that you want then you just Define and what you get at the end of that is an
invocation endpoint and this is where you fire your url requests to with all that information to interact with your
resources and get back that those representations and this is the architecture that you're really aiming
to build up where you have your front-end applications mobile applications websites you have other
backend applications services that are either coming from third parties or you own yourself connecting directly to the
API Gateway and that API Gateway is receiving and managing all the requests for the API and sending them on either
to ec2 endpoints to Lambda functions that you configure or to any other publicly accessible endpoint but it

that makes it much easier to manage the scale of your backend applications that's built directly into the gateway

application API we add metering and throttling so you can see who's doing doing what and get in-depth logs and
